title: Musing Your Life into Action

Musing Your Life into Action

Relentless, methodical productivity hacks don’t work for everyone.

Bride In Reverse
Apr 1

I’m a recovering To-Do list addict.

I used to write lists endlessly to make sure I didn’t forget anything. I’d make them for how I planned to spend my weekend — household chores, social outings and all. I’d do them for when I was getting ready for a dinner party. I’d create them for reaching health and fitness goals.

Then one day I realized my inability to get everything checked off my lists was making me feel even worse than not being productive at all, and what I really needed to do was get into the mindset of completing a task. By jumping in to make things happen and not bothering with writing a list and thinking too much about it, I got soooo much more done. In short, I stopped deliberating and started doing, which helped me not worry incessantly about the task at hand, or drift off into distraction.

BUT … I still love jotting things down. It’s a habit I’ve had since I was a kid, when I began writing in notebooks all the time. My number one recommended item I think everyone should have, when they’re trying to mentally get organized and take stock of what needs to happen but, like me, bristle at the idea of bullet journals and list-making? A dry erase board.

I finally got one for my apartment to stick on my fridge and absolutely love it. Instead of keeping lists on it, I write down something I’m curious about or will enjoy reading over and over again, like my menu I’m making for the week or a fragment of poetry that might grow into a poem someday. These sound like random bits of information, but seeing my menu reminds me I don’t need to spend money on going out to eat and can focus more on budget-savvy wellness, like eating home-cooked meals. Seeing a whisper from my imagination, like a few words that might turn into a poem, supports my ongoing need to be creative and to commit to being a better writer. I’m turning to my imagination and saying, “I SEE you. I know you’re trying to tell me something right now, but I’m too busy at the moment to go all in. I’ll write down what you said and check back later.”

Sometimes these little notes to myself on my dry erase board become self-help sorts of gestures. For example, on the first day of my new job back in January, I wrote this on my dry erase board. I live by myself and have to cheer myself on sometimes, even though it feels silly at first:

The latest random thing I wrote on my dry erase board? “It’s a water time, not a fire time.” Not sure where that phrase came from in my mind, but I think it has something to do with how I’m not dating anyone at the moment, taking time to just exist, be more reflective and let things drift along. It’s a good place to be, at least for now.

So if you’re one of those people who can’t deal with structured organizational methods because they stress you out, maybe try a dry erase board to help you learn to listen to yourself. It’s a nice way to check in and mull things over while you’re running around your home doing boring housework, etc. It also frees you up to honor your creativity, even if it’s just a quick note you write down to revisit later, when you’re ready to sit and write or paint or whatever you want to do to express yourself.

Grow where you’re planted

I live in Washington, D.C. I moved here five years ago when I decided to basically reboot my life and start over, post-divorce.

D.C. is a city of travelers and tourists — people coming and going all the time. Many of my friends and the men I’ve dated here all travel frequently for their jobs or for fun. The city is always full of visitors, too, people who are proud and excited to be in the nation’s capital.

D.C.’s transitory nature is part of what makes it so exciting. But it can also make residents feel a little sad at times, like life is happening all around you but is so damn fleeting.

Now that I’ve been here five years, I’m becoming that type of D.C. resident who is comfortable with my old haunts, traditions and favorite places. The cherry blossoms are beautiful here right now, but so are the trees and yards all over my neighborhood. I guess what I’m trying to say is I’m not necessarily running out to have every high-powered, incredible DCist experience any more, but I am in love with this city, every time I walk out the door and explore the streets. That day-to-day enchantment makes me so happy. For example, I was walking home from a yoga class this past weekend and looked up and saw this Japanese magnolia with the sun shining through all the blossoms. It took my breath away and reminded me that I don’t need to pressure myself to be at the coolest experience ever, around the clock.

Sometimes moment-to-moment inspiration is where it’s at. Not only does it let you go with the flow a little more, but it helps you become more aware of how grateful you should be for your daily existence. Gratitude is heralded as a HUGE thing with how people can stay on track with creating lives they love. I try to find a moment of gratitude every day, and that doesn’t necessarily mean chasing down the latest, hottest thing in D.C. a lot of people here think is how you celebrate being alive. For example, my friends will tease me about this, but I don’t think I’m a pop-up bar person, though the pop-up scene is pretty impressive in this city. I don’t want to go to a pop-up bar to stand in a long line and get an over-priced mediocre cocktail just because it’s cherry blossom season. But I’ll gladly take walking around my neighborhood and soaking up all the spring flora, and then maybe meeting someone later for a drink at a really cool local spot I know.

I’m coming into my own here, and I love this city so much. But I’m not putting pressure on myself to have the same experiences as everyone else. And that’s okay. I’m more productive and focused when I do what’s right for me and where I’m at in my life.

Art is everywhere

My final productivity recommendation? Free up your mind to just wander around and be immersed in a cultural experience.

I used to telework once a week, and sometimes, when the stars aligned and I didn’t have too many work calls, I’d go to the American Art Museum/National Portrait Gallery’s Kogod Courtyard. There, I’d do focused work and then on my lunch break or at the end of my day, I’d reward myself by walking around and looking at the latest exhibitions, or simply enjoy the beautiful courtyard space itself. I’d often find that by shifting gears and seeking out cultural experiences, I’d suddenly come up with a solution to a problem at my job, or get a great idea for a project I was working on.

Pressing pause and doing something artsy — whether it’s admiring graffiti in your neighborhood, actively exploring a museum, or pulling out some crayons to fill up doodles in a coloring book — can be just the thing to help you get back into gear and tackle a challenge in a new way. Try different experiences and see what feels right for you.

  • Productivity
  • Self Improvement
  • Personal Development
  • Growth

  • Bride In Reverse

    Medium member since Mar 2017

    Creating relevant conversations about becoming someone new after divorce. Posts by Becca Bycott. Facebook Group: http://bit.ly/BrideinReverseFacebookGroup

  • Age of Awareness

    Stories providing creative, innovative, and sustainable changes to the education system

title_html: Musing Your Life into Action
